duck: Lemma (morphology), the canonical form or citation form of a word
Lemma (botany), one of the specialised bracts enclosing a floret in a grass inflorescence
lemma definition: an auxiliary proposition used in the demonstration of another proposition.
Lemma (mathematics), a proven statement used as a stepping-stone toward the proof of another statement
Lemma (logic), which is simultaneously a premise for a contention above it and a contention for premises below it
Analemma, the curve traced out by a celestial body over the course of a year on the celestial sphere of another body; a phenomenon that may be used to determine the time of year
Lemma (psycholinguistics), an intermediate form a word about to be uttered takes during speech production

milestones: British computer scientist's new "nullity" idea provokes reaction from mathematicians

wiki.text:
In morphology and lexicography, a 'lemma' (plural lemmas or lemmata) is the
'canonical form', 'dictionary form', or 'citation form' of a set of words
(headword). In English, for example, run, runs, ran and running are forms of the
same lexeme, with run as the lemma. Lexeme, in this context, refers to the set
of all the forms that have the same meaning, and lemma refers to the particular
form that is chosen by convention to represent the lexeme. In lexicography, this
unit is usually also the citation form or headword by which it is indexed.
Lemmas have special significance in highly inflected languages such as Turkish
and Czech. The process of determining the lemma for a given word is called
lemmatisation.
wiki.title: Lemma%20%28morphology%29
